PROJECT SUMMARY 

East  Timor's  transport  and  power  infrastructure  was  severely 
damaged  during  the  postreferendum  conflict  and  was  unable  to 
facilitate  humanitarian  relief  or  security  operations.  The  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  prepared  and  administered  a  grant 
funded  by  the  Trust  Fund  for  East  Timor  (TFET)  for  the 
Emergency  Infrastructure  Rehabilitation  Project  (EIRP)  to  restore 
road  conditions,  port  operations,  and  power  supply  to  enable 
humanitarian  aid  delivery  and  resumption  of  economic  activities. 
The needs of the infrastructure sectors, particularly for road sector 
restoration,  require  additional  funding  over  and  above  the  initial 
grant.  Supplementary  resources  for  the  EIRP  are  to  support 
restoration  of  the  road  conditions  to  a  standard  where  the  road 
network  can  make  a  contribution  to  economic  activities  and  be 
maintained by an East Timorese field maintenance administration. 
 
East Timor 
 
The  Emergency  Infrastructure  Rehabilitation  Project  (Phase  2) 
(EIRP-2) will intensify and extend the objectives of the EIRP and 
focus on stabilizing the road network leaving it in a condition that 
can  be  maintained  with  a  relatively  modest  budget.  The  EIRP-2 
will  also  continue  programs  to  establish  a  viable  and  efficient 
maintenance operation in East Timor. 
 
The EIRP-2 will provide (i) sustainable road works that reduce the 
annual  emergency  rehabilitation  requirement,  (ii)  support  for 
establishing a road maintenance regime, (iii) detailed engineering 
services, and (iv) project management services and training. 
 
The  EIRP-2  is  classified  as  environmental  category  B.  An  initial 
environmental  examination  was  undertaken,  and  its  summary  is 
included as a core appendix. 
 
The  immediate  benefits  of  the  EIRP-2  include  (i)  improvement  of 
access to rural areas, (ii) inducement of agricultural cultivation, (iii) 
reduction  of  urbanization 
facilitation  of 
humanitarian  aid  programs  and  security  conditions.  The  EIRP-2 
will  employ  local  communities,  focusing  on  the  poorest  in  rural 
areas  where  most  people  have  very  limited  income-generating 
opportunities.  Local  communities  will  also  be  employed  under  a 
sustainable  and 
long-term  road  maintenance  program,  and 
opportunities  and  training  programs  will  be  provided  for  the 
emerging road industry.

I. 

THE PROJECT 

1. 
I submit for your information the following report on a supplementary grant to East Timor 
for  the  Emergency  Infrastructure  Rehabilitation  Project  (Phase  2)  (EIRP-2).1  The  project 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 

II. 

INTRODUCTION 

2. 
In January 2000, the United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor (UNTAET) 
asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to prepare and administer emergency assistance to 
rehabilitate damaged infrastructure for early restoration of normal socioeconomic activities. An 
ADB  appraisal  mission2  visited  East  Timor  in  February  2000  and  prepared  the  EIRP.3 
Negotiations for the Grant Agreement for the Project were completed with UNTAET on 29 March 
2000, and became effective on 19 April 2000. Funding for the grant is drawn from the Trust Fund 
for  East  Timor  (TFET),  which  is  established  under  the  trusteeship  of  the  International 
Development  Agency  of  the  World  Bank  Group.  The  TFET  does  not  include  ADB’s  own 
resources. Implementation of the EIRP commenced in late April and disbursements in May 2000.  
 
3. 
The  project  management  unit  (PMU)  began  operations  in  April  2000  with  both 
international  and  East  Timorese  staff.  In  May  2000,  the  PMU  issued  the  first  work  orders  to 
repair the worst road closures. In June, five major contracts were implemented on the main road 
sections to facilitate road access during the rainy season in the third quarter of 2000. Since then 
a  total  of  66  road  rehabilitation  contracts,  involving  a  significant  share  of  East  Timorese 
contractors  and  consultants,  have  been  awarded  under  the  EIRP.  The  impact  of  these  works 
has been significant in facilitating humanitarian aid to rural areas and enhancing the revival of 
economic activities since the September 1999 crisis. 
 
In  August  2000,  the  EIRP  completed  upgrading  a  container  terminal  yard  and  an 
4. 
incomplete  third  berth,  and  repaired  a  landing  slip  at  Dili  Port.  These  actions  have  reduced 
congestion  of  port  premises  and  contributed  to  reducing  vessel  queuing  time,  thus  enhancing 
delivery  of  goods  and  aid.  Also  in  August  2000,  the  21  rural  power  stations  assigned  to  the 
EIRP  were  assessed.  Work  on  the  power  station  was  delayed  due  to  the  gradual  award  of 
disbursement  authority  resulting  from  delayed  cash  receipts  in  the  TFET  and  poor  security 
conditions along the western border of East Timor. The rehabilitation works are now estimated 
to  require  $2.4  million,  and  a  difficult  prioritization  process  has  been  carried  out  to  adjust  the 
work program to the available funding.  
 
5. 
The infrastructure sectors, and most pressingly roads, suffer from immediate needs that 
require funding beyond the EIRP and the limited bilateral resources. Additional funding of $9.0 
million has become available from the TFET for the infrastructure sectors. UNTAET asked ADB 
to prepare the project documentation for and administer implementation of the new allocation. 
Subsequently, appraisal was carried out from 14 to 28 February 2001.4 Objectives, scope, and 
implementation  were  agreed  in  a  memorandum  of  understanding.  In  light  of  the  limited 
availability  of  additional  funding,  the  sector  needs  have  been  considered  under  a  rigorous

 2 

prioritization process. The new supplementary allocation EIRP-2 will continue and intensify the 
efforts  made  under  the  EIRP  and  support  the  EIRP's  objectives.  In  particular,  the  EIRP-2  will 
focus  on  restoring  the  road  network  to  a  condition,  where  routine  maintenance  will  effectively 
extend  its  economic  life.  This  report  is  prepared  in  accordance  with  the  Joint  Management 
Arrangements for the Trust Fund for East Timor.5 
 

III. 

BACKGROUND 

A. 

Response to Crisis 

the 

6. 
Description of Damage. In the democratic consultation of 30 August 1999, the people 
of  East  Timor  voted  overwhelmingly  for  independence.  This  was  followed  by  a  campaign  of 
destruction,  during  which  three  quarters  of  the  population  fled  their  homes  and  most  of  the 
country’s  infrastructure,  commerce,  and  private  homes  were  destroyed.  Most  of  the  refugees 
have  now  returned  from  West  Timor  and  the  forest,  and  have  settled  with  the  support  of 
humanitarian relief. Consequent to the postreferendum destruction, all administrative structures 
became dysfunctional, including public offices tasked to manage the infrastructure sectors.  
 
7. 
Administration.  A  resolution  of  the  United  Nations  Security  Council  established 
UNTAET to ensure stability and establish a transitional government prior to formation of an East 
Timorese  administration.  General  elections  were  conducted  on  30  August  2001,  and  an  East 
Timorese  Second  Transitional  Administration  through  its  cabinet  of  members  assumed 
responsibility for economic development as delegated under UNTAET Regulation No. 2001/28. 
UNTAET administered East Timor until 19 May 2002. On 20 May 2002, East Timor gained its 
independence  and  is  now  governed  as  a  republic  with  a  democratically  elected  president  and 
parliament,  and  a  prime  minister-led  government.  Under  its  Resolution  No.  1412  of  17  May 
2002,  the  Security  Council  established  a  United  Nations  Mission  in  East  Timor  to  support  the 
core  administrative  structures  critical  to  the  viability  and  political  stability  of  East  Timor.  In 
that  had  managed 
September  2001, 
telecommunications,  postal  services,  electricity,  water  and  sanitation,  and  transport,  including 
roads,  ports,  and  aviation,  was  replaced  by  the  Ministry  of  Water  and  Public  Works  (MWPW) 
responsible  for  roads,  water,  buildings  and  the  Government's  civil  works  and  the  Ministry  of 
Communications and Transport responsible for ports, airports and land transport. 
 
8. 
Recurrent  Budget.  The  Government's  recurrent  budget  is  drawn  from  donor  funding. 
Expenditures  are  primarily  salaries  for  East  Timorese  employees  and  recurrent  consumables 
such as fuel. The capital development budget, drawn from the TFET, was assessed by a World 
Bank-coordinated  multiagency  joint  assessment  mission  (JAM)  in  October-November  1999. 
Comprehensive  sector  budgets,  prepared  with  ADB  support,  reflect  significant  shortfalls 
between the needs and trust fund contributions in the recurrent and capital budgets.  
 
9. 
Poverty.  East  Timor’s  poverty  profile  is  dramatically  affected  by  the  massive  political, 
economic, and social upheaval in September 1999.6 As a result of the postreferendum violence, 
cash  incomes  became  nonexistent  for  most  of  the  population.  In  1996,  when  East  Timor  was 
part of Indonesia, its gross domestic product (GDP) per capita income was $431, or 37% of the 
                                                 
5  R74-00: Joint Management Arrangements for the Trust Fund for East Timor, 23 March 2000. 
6  ADB.  2000.  Regional  Technical  Assistance  for  Poverty  Assessment  in  Pacific  Developing  Member  Countries. 
Manila.  The  official  Indonesian  poverty  line  is  calculated  using  the  social  survey  undertaken  by  the  Indonesian 
Bureau of Statistics. This is defined as the cost of ensuring a minimum daily food consumption of 2,100 kilocalories 
per person. 

former  Department  of 

Infrastructure 

 

 3 

Indonesian national average. As a result of the Asian crisis, poverty increased, and the decline 
in  East  Timor's  GDP  was  more  pronounced  than  that  of  Indonesia  due  to  its  dependence  on 
Indonesian central government grants. The number of households living below the Indonesian 
official poverty line rose to an estimated 50 to 60% from 30% in 1996. From 1998, the average 
income  of  the  poor  (those  living  below  the  poverty  line)  steadily  increased  to  about  7%  of 
population in 1999 from 2% less than the poverty line. The poor are characterized by a lack of 
education, low literacy, high dependency burdens, and dependence on subsistence agriculture. 
Farming is the primary occupation of 85% of household heads. 
 
10. 
Restoration  Programs.  In  response  to  the  crisis,  the  United  Nations  Office  for 
Coordination  of  Humanitarian  Affairs  coordinated  immediate  humanitarian  relief  programs 
during  the  first  three  months  from  December  1999.  To  plan  for  the  urgent  medium-term 
rehabilitation  in  a  coordinated  manner,  ADB  joined  the  JAM  in  October-November  1999.  As  a 
result, ADB and the World Bank agreed to work together on the reconstruction of East Timor, 
with ADB as the lead agency for restoring the infrastructure sectors. Subsequently, ADB's Board 
approved  a  delegated  approval  authority  for  project  proposals  by  ADB's  Management, 
in 
expanded  eligibility  under  ADB's  procurement  guidelines,  disbursement  procedures 
accordance  with  ADB's  disbursement  guidelines,  and  establishment  of  grant  agreements  for 
projects funded from the TFET (footnote 5).7 
 
The ADB-funded technical assistance (TA) for transport sector restoration8 implemented 
11. 
ADB’s  first  intervention  in  the  three  transport  subsectors  by  taking  steps  to  establish  the 
institutions  and  regulatory  frameworks  in  the  road,  port,  and  airport  subsectors,  and  by 
reviewing the long-term development requirements. Further TA will be implemented to prepare 
legal frameworks for the new institutions and implement effective agency operations. The TAs 
and the EIRP work in tandem to support the process for establishing appropriately scaled sector 
operations in East Timor.  
 
B. 

Transport Subsector Description 

12. 
East Timor forms the eastern half of Timor Island, and includes the islands of Atauro and 
Joco  and  the  Oecusse  enclave,  on  the  north  coast  of  the  island  within  Indonesian  territory.  It 
stretches for 250 kilometers (km) east to west and 80 km north to south at the widest point with 
an  area  of  14,900  square  kilometers  (km2).9  The  terrain  is  dominated  by  a  spinal  range  of 
mountains reaching nearly 3,000 meters (m) at the highest point. Narrow plains characterize the 
north  and  south  coasts.  The  hinterland  consists  mainly  of  mountains  and  intervening  narrow 
valleys, which become broader and flatter in the east with extensive limestone plateaus.  
 
13. 
The transport system in East Timor is multimodal, comprising about 5,000 km of roads; 
one  container  port,  three  smaller  wharves,  small  jetties,  and  landings;  and  two  international 
airports and eight grass airstrips. The past demand on the transport system in East Timor was 
that  of  a  provincial  economy.  All  internal  traffic  in  East  Timor  depended  on  land  transport, 
awarding  the  road  sector  a  paramount  role.  Benefits  from  intermodal  linkages  are  minimal  as 
domestic  maritime  transport  is  not  available,  and  the  potential  for  inland  and  southern  coastal 

                                                 
7  The  delegated  authority  provides  an  arrangement  for  the  TFET  and  an  expansion  of  eligibility  under  ADB's 
procurement and engagement of consultant guidelines to include member countries, East Timor, and all donor and 
member of international organizations that have provided contribution funds to the TFET. 
8  ADB. 2000. Technical Assistance to East Timor for Transport Sector Restoration. Manila. 
9  Slightly  larger  than  Vanuatu  (12,200  km2),  but  smaller  than  the  Fiji  Islands  (18,300  km2),  and  a  third  the  size  of 

Bhutan (47,000 km2). 

 4 

maritime transport suffers from weather and seasonal impact. Aviation is thwarted on account of 
affordability.  
 

1. 

Roads 

a. 

Description 

14. 
The road network is supported by the main coastal east-west arteries along the northern 
and southern coastlines. The north-south secondary roads connect these two links. The network 
consists  of  some  1,200  km  of  main  roads,  2,000  km  of  district  roads,  and  about  1,800  km  of 
feeder  roads.  The  road  network  is  relatively  dense  considering  the  low  level  of  economic 
development  and  sparse  population  with  approximately  1  km  of  road  for  3  km2;  about  50%  of 
roads were sealed at one time. 
 
15. 
However,  this  network  is  challenged  by  young  geology  and  weather  conditions.  Forty 
percent  of  the  land  is  on  steep  slopes.  The  tectonic  conditions  of  the  island  endow  it  with 
sedimentary  sandstone  and  calcareous  rocks  with  some  basic  igneous  material;  these  rocks 
comprise  conglomerates;  reef  limestone;  and  alluvial  cobble,  sand,  and  silt  deposits.  From  an 
engineering  viewpoint,  these  conditions  and  the  lightweight  nature  of  the  pavement  require 
annual  maintenance  action.  As  a  result,  roads  remain  fragile  and  susceptible  to  a  monsoon 
climate  that  even  under  the  best  conditions  would  require  a  moderate  to  high  level  of 
maintenance.  From  an  engineering  viewpoint,  the  geology  even  without  earthworks  or 
agriculture  makes  roads  highly  susceptible  to  severe  annual  landslides.  Many  routes  are  also 
crossed  by  a  number  of  large  braided  rivers10  with  a  combination  of  bridges  and  causeways. 
These causeways are vulnerable to the natural realignment of the waterways. During the rainy 
season, rivers flood the roads and interrupt the transport system.  
 
16.  While  most  of  the  main  road  network  was  sealed,  the  road  surfaces  on  the  minor 
network have now deteriorated to gravel. The sealed network was built to a minimum standard 
to  provide  all-weather  access  to  small  and  light  vehicle  traffic.  The  lightweight  nature  of  the 
pavement has not been viable, and could only be so if kept well drained and vehicle axle loads 
restricted.  Although  the  Indonesian  Government  spent  most  public  funds  on  infrastructure, 
infrastructure systems in East Timor remained underdeveloped. Road repairs and maintenance 
were  inadequately  funded.  Eighty  percent  of  the  1997/98  infrastructure  budget  of  $5.8  million, 
funded both centrally and locally, implemented roadworks in East Timor. In the following year, 
this was reduced by 22%, with the road improvement budget falling by 25%, road rehabilitation 
by 65%, and maintenance by 14%.  
 
17. 
All  roads  have  suffered  from  the  long-term  neglect  of  maintenance.  The  maintenance 
challenge was compounded by the low design standard adopted and the changing course of the 
many north-south braided rivers. The roads, built for low volumes and light traffic, and then used 
by  the  heavy  vehicles  of  the  transitional  administration,  have  deteriorated  further.  As  a 
consequence,  the  network  has  incurred  a  large  backlog  of  road  repair  needs  in  addition  to 
ordinary  routine  maintenance.  While  the  EIRP  is  addressing  the  backlog  requirement,  if  the 
network is to be left in a reasonable and maintainable condition at project completion, additional 

                                                 
10 Braided river denotes a river with a wide river valley and an unidentified primary river channel subject to changing 
location due to because of frequent changes in river flow and sediment supply. As the channels of a braided river 
change course frequently, they risk to eventually cover an entire valley floor, which then would experience flooding 
on  a  regular  basis. A  braided  river  typically  has  no  conventional  floodplain.  In  contrast  to  braided  rivers, 
meandering rivers typically only contain one channel that winds its way across the floodplain. As it flows, it deposits 
sediment on banks that lie on the insides of curves and erode the banks on the outside of curves. 

 5 

resources  will  be  required  to  clear  the  maintenance  backlog.  Road  drainage  clearance  and 
restoration is also being carried under the EIRP, and needs to be continued on a regular basis 
by a sustainable maintenance operation.  

 

b. 

Medium- to Long-Term Sector Development  

18. 
Economic  Context.  The  road  network  is  an  extremely  valuable  asset  for  East  Timor. 
Given  the  foreseeable  economic  circumstances  of  the  country,  an  extensively  paved  national 
road  network  is  an  irreplaceable  national  endowment  that  could  be  irreparably  damaged  if 
regular  maintenance  is  not  instituted  as  a  matter  of  urgency.  GDP  growth  in  East  Timor  is 
projected11 until 2003 at 15% per annum as a result of reconstruction. From 2004 to 2010, the 
annual GDP growth rate is forecast at 10% due to the impact of full production from the Timor 
Gap oil fields. Growth is projected to stabilize at 7% from 2011 to 2015 and at 5% from 2015 to 
2030.  The  growth  drivers—agricultural  production,  crops,  and  livestock—need  transport 
services.  Traffic  for  forestry,  fishing,  tourism,  other  service  activities,  and  microenterprises  will 
grow in direct proportion to the growth drivers. Only with adequate accessibility will production 
activities  diversify  and  intensify  and  the  benefits  of  increased  productivity,  employment, 
population, and per capita income will follow. 
 
19. 
Transport  Sector  Plan.  The  role  of  a  sound  transport  sector  plan  is  central  for 
identification  of  the  transport  sector  linkages  with  the  productive  sectors  and  macroeconomic 
development,  sector  management,  operation  and  maintenance,  intermodal  planning,  and 
cohesive  investment  programs  and  work  plans.  A  draft  multimodal  transport  sector  plan  was 
prepared  under  the  Transport  Sector  Restoration  TA  (footnote  8)  for  the  consideration  of  the 
new government as a national transport plan.  
 
20. 
Sector Administration. The transport subsectors are currently managed by MWPW by 
a minister and a vice-minister. These are supported by a director general and a small staff. The 
low levels of East Timorese staff have constrained the capacity building process. In July 2000, 
the  National  Cabinet  of  East  Timor  approved  the  drafting  of  a  transport  act  to  provide  for  the 
establishment of ports, airports, and road under one legislative instrument. The advantages of 
one legal instrument are clarity and ability to extract all economies of scale in organizing sector 
administration. Legal and structural establishment of transport sector administration is pending. 
UNTAET  requested  ADB-funded  TA  to  (i)  draft  legislation  and  (ii)  support  implementation  of 
efficient  organizations  that  would  be  directly  accountability  to  the  government  and  users  for 
policy  and  strategy  implementation  for  service  provision,  and  management  efficiency.  TA  for 
Transport Sector Improvement was approved on 1 October 200112 for this purpose. 
 
21. 
Requirements. The road budget in Appendix 2 provides a view of the requirements for a 
basic  road  service.  This  service  level  facilitates  access  to  most  villages,  delivery  of  minimal 
social  services,  and  transport  needs  of  agricultural  produce  to  the  main  markets.  The  budget 
also  records  currently  available  funding  for  roads.  With  the  EIRP-2  and  the  EIRP  successfully 
reducing the backlog maintenance requirement to a minimum, maintaining 1,200 km of the total 
of 5,000 km of roads in their current condition is estimated to cost about $9.3 million per annum. 
This figure comprises road agency costs of $3.4 million, and routine and emergency monsoon 
maintenance costs of $4.4 million and $1.5 million.

Rationale 

The EIRP has aimed to support humanitarian assistance in East Timor by rehabilitating

Timorese with access to the humanitarian relief aid.

27. 
The EIRP objective is to (i) undertake emergency road repair works to facilitate efficient 
transport of humanitarian aid and security cargo, and to induce revival of economic activity; (ii) 
expand  the  capacity  of  port  facilities  to  reduce  congestion;  and  (iii)  reinstate  power  supply.  In 
addition  to  its  emergency  nature,  the  EIRP  supports  long-term  sector  development  by 
strengthening  the  local  contracting  industry,  instituting  operational  and  maintenance  systems, 
and providing capacity building for sector management.

V. 

THE EMERGENCY INFRASTRUCTURE REHABILITATION PROJECT (PHASE 2) 

A. 

Rationale 

53.  While  East  Timor  inherited  a  relatively  dense  and,  to  a  large  extent,  sealed  road 
network,  road  maintenance  has  been  severely  neglected.  The  inherent  instability  of  the  hilly 
topography,  the  vulnerability  of  the  coastal  network  to  flooding  and  river  realignment,  and  the 
sensitivity  of  road  pavements  to  poor  drainage,  all  combine  to  make  a  high  maintenance 
network.  The  condition  of  the  southern  coastal  road  varies  greatly:  some  sections  are  paved 
and are in good condition, while others are little more than tracks. The route crosses a number 
of  large  braided  rivers  with  a  combination  of  bridges  and  causeways.  These  causeways  are 
vulnerable  to  the  natural  realignment  of  the  waterways.  The  two  major  bridges,  Punta  Cassa 
and Zumalai, are incomplete. Five national and provincial north-south roads, all showing severe 
signs of neglect, provide vehicular access from Dili and the northern east-west road to the south 

 12 

coast. During the rainy season, rivers flood these roads and interrupt the transport system. Data 
on road conditions in East Timor demonstrate that a majority of district roads are in poor or very 
poor  condition,  and  that  a  strong  linkage  exists  between  road  network  conditions  and 
commercial activity. 
 
54. 
The road network remains fragile. Under normal conditions, the network would require a 
high level of maintenance. However, in the past seven years maintenance has been neglected, 
and in the years following the Asian crises since 1997, halted. Recurrent maintenance of gravel 
roads  is  much  more  costly  than  that  of  paved  roads,  even  taking  due  account  of  the  different 
service  levels.  A  reduced  service  level  will  not  result  in  significant  savings  in  routine 
maintenance costs. For example, the budget required to maintain a two-day access to Maliana 
on a gravel surface is the same as that needed to maintain a half-day access using the present 
paved surface.  
 
55. 
The  EIRP  has  implemented  road  repair  works  in  addition  to  its  port  and  power 
components. The road repair works have been invaluable in facilitating access to humanitarian 
aid and peace and security. However, these have addressed immediate road closures and have 
only  partially  been  able  to  implement  permanent  engineering  solutions  that  will  reduce  the 
maintenance burden in the long term. This program requires additional resources. The EIRP is 
also  supporting  longer-term  sector  development,  establishment  of  routine  maintenance 
mechanisms,  field  organization,  local  contracting  industry,  community  engagement,  and 
capacity  building  for  sector  management.  Accordingly,  the  additional  funding  will  focus  on 
intensifying and extending the EIRP objective to restore the road network to a condition in which 
its  economic  life  can  be  extended  effectively  through  routine  maintenance  within  available 
recurrent funding levels. 
 
B. 

Objectives  

In  light  of  the  forecasted  recurrent  budgetary  constraints  of  the  emerging  East  Timor, 
56. 
the EIRP-2 will focus on stabilizing the road network and enabling it to be left in a condition from 
which  it  can  be  maintained  with  a  relatively  modest  budget.  The  objective  of  the  EIRP-2  is  to 
support  earthworks  to  diminish  the  annually  recurring  emergency  requirement  by  reducing  the 
backlog  maintenance  requirement.  It  will  also  continue  programs  initiated  under  the  EIRP  to 
establish  a  viable  and  efficient  maintenance  operation  in  East  Timor  and  support  technical 
preparation  of  the  East  Timorese  maintenance  service  to  carry  out  routine  maintenance  and 
contract village groups. 
  
C.

rehabilitation  requirements,  and  support  for  the  establishment  of  a  road  maintenance  regime.

F. 

Technical Approach  

1. 

Civil Works to Reduce Emergency Maintenance Requirement 

60. 
Earthworks.  The  earthworks  rehabilitation  will  support  the  reconstruction  and  minor 
realignment of short road sections that have become unstable and have potential for technical 
correction. The soils, topography, and climate combined render the road network vulnerable to 
landslides.  Clearing  and  repairing  these  is  a  major  component  of  the  recurrent  maintenance 
activities.  Annual  repairs  cannot  effectively  and  economically  reinstate  the  extensive  landslip 
sites. More permanent solutions are required through improved alignment and fully engineered 
slope stabilization works and bioengineering techniques. This component will initiate a strategy 
for  preventive  civil  works  for  bench16  failures  that  are  currently  absorbing  an  unacceptable 
proportion of the recurrent budget. A tentative list of roads, from which sections will be identified, 
is in Appendix 5.  

                                                 
16  A  bench  failure  is  a  slip  of  the  ground  beneath  the  road,  where  the  road  was  originally  formed  by  a  cut  into  the 
hillside, caused commonly caused by a slide in the land fill placed on the sloping hillside to create a level bench for 
the road. 

 14 

 
61. 
Bioengineering.  Bioengineering  techniques  will  be  used  to  enhance  slope  stability. 
Under  these  techniques,  indigenous  plants  will  be  identified  that  will  effectively  reduce  soil 
moisture,  resist  surface  erosion,  and  bind  surfaces  with  strong  and  deep  root  systems.  Once 
appropriate plants are identified, small nurseries will be established, and optimum planting and 
care strategies identified, demonstrated, and implemented. 
 
62. 
Periodic Maintenance. Periodic maintenance requirements cost about $12 million per 
annum.  This  reinstates  road  surfaces  damaged  by  traffic  abrasion  and  wet  season  erosion. 
Most roads have lost the integrity of their wearing surfaces. Consequently, they deteriorate too 
rapidly  for  routine  maintenance  to  be  effective,  and  have  become  impassable  in  wet  weather. 
While an ideal periodic maintenance program would resurface about one seventh of the network 
each year, periodic road resurfacing is required at intervals of 5 to 10 years. However, no such 
program has been implemented during the past four years, and as much as 60% of the network 
is overdue for resurfacing treatment. Sites needing work most urgently will be identified and this 
treatment  strategy  initiated.  A  small  bridge  replacement  program  will  support  the  repair  or 
replacement of substandard and vulnerable major drainage structures on the main roads. 

 
2. 

Support to Establish a Routine Maintenance Regime 

Steep slopes, erodible sedimentary materials, and intense rainfall characterize the road 
63. 
network  environment.  Under  these  conditions  even  minor  slips  and  drain  blockages  result  in 
road  sections  becoming  impassible  after  heavy  rainfall.  Under  the  EIRP  village  groups  are 
responsible  for  maintaining  the  road  drainage  system;  eventually,  funding  for  this  will  be 
transferred  to  recurrent  budget  of  the  Government.  The  EIRP-2  provide  technical  support  to 
establish the community-based maintenance program and related technical capacity in the field 
organization. 
 

3. 

Project Management and Training 

The  EIRP-2  will  use 

the  established  project  management  and 

64. 
implementation 
arrangements agreed for the EIRP, including the PMU reporting to the minister of MWPW. The 
PMU  organization  chart  is  in  Appendix  6.  The  EIRP-2  will  support  the  incremental  time  and 
personnel requirements of the PMU. The PMU will engage geotechnical and design engineering 
services and other short-term specialists, as required.  
 
Significant  skills  upgrading  is  needed  to  enable  the  East  Timorese  to  assume 
65. 
managerial and technical responsibility for implementing the routine and periodic maintenance 
regime,  bio-  and  other  engineering  techniques,  and  financial  and  administrative  accountability 
for  the  sector.  Under  the  EIRP,  immediate,  and  medium-  and  long-term  training  requirements 
are  being  identified  under  a  comprehensive  human  resource  development  assessment,  which 
will  determine  the  specific  skills  required  for  the  planned  institutional  arrangements  for  the 
sector (para. 24). The EIRP-2 will provide the technical training to establish technical capability 
of  the  road  maintenance  organization.  However,  this  program  is  likely  to  require  additional 
resources, and the PMU of EIRP-2 will make all efforts to identify cofinancing for this purpose.  
 
G. 

Implementation Arrangements 

Executing Agency. East Timor will be the recipient of the grant and MWPW will be the 
66. 
Executing  Agency.  The  PMU  will  be  the  project  implementing  agency  and  will  report  to  the 
minister of MWPW. The PMU will program, administer, and coordinate daily activities. It will be 

 15 

technical  adviser  will  support 

headed  by  an  East  Timorese  project  manager  and  comprise  an  internationally  recruited  chief 
technical adviser, engineers, and an accountant. The selection of these will be subject to ADB's 
approval.  The  chief 
the  project  manager  with  EIRP-2 
administration and its contracts in accordance with ADB guidelines. The chief technical adviser 
will be accountable to ADB for the quality and timeliness of project implementation. Engineers 
will  program  and  coordinate  daily  project  activities,  including  design,  supervision,  procurement 
of goods and services, and management of civil works contracts. The international consultants 
will train East Timorese counterparts in their areas of responsibility.  
 
67. 
Steering  Committee.  MWPW  will  establish,  in  consultation  with  other  relevant 
ministries, a Steering Committee for the Project to involve a broader stakeholder representation 
in  Project  implementation.  The  Steering  Committee  will  be  convened  every  two  months  to 
discuss  and  resolve  emerging  issues  in  Project  implementation,  workplans,  review  and 
comment on the Project reports, and the attainment of Project objectives. 
 
68. 
Consultant Services. International and domestic consulting services will be required for 
(i) project management and (ii) detailed engineering. These consultant services will be selected 
in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  However,  the  term  "member 
countries"  under  these  guidelines  for  purposes  of  the  EIRP-2  will  include  ADB  member 
countries,  East  Timor,  and  all  donors  and  members  of  international  organizations  that  have 
provided  contribution  funds  to  the  TFET.  Individual  consulting  services  will  be  selected  for 
project management. The PMU will be funded under the Project. The PMU's terms of reference 
are  in  Appendix  7.  Slope  stabilization  requires  geotechnical  assessment  of  the  soil  conditions 
and  detailed  engineering.  These  services  will  be  selected  from  an  international  firm.  Outline 
terms  of  reference  for  detailed  design  are  in  Appendix  8.  Advance  procurement  action  for 
detailed engineering was approved. 
 
69. 
Procurement. All procurement for the EIRP-2 will be carried out using international and 
the local competitive bidding and international shopping procedures in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines for Procurement (footnote 5 and 7). Contractors will be eligible to tender for one or 
more  of  the  contract  packages  within  their  respective  bid  capacities.  ADB  approval  prior  to 
award will be required for all contracts. Tentative procurement packages are in Appendix 9. 
 
70. 
Implementation  Schedule.  Programs  under  the  EIRP-2  will  be  implemented  over  18 
months from June 2002 and be completed by December 2003. Advance procurement action for 
the  selection  of  detailed  engineering  consultants  has  commenced  in  January  2001.  The 
implementation schedule is in Appendix 10.  
 
71. 
Disbursement.  The  EIRP-2  will  be  disbursed  under  the  (i)  imprest  account,  (ii)  direct 
payment, and (iii) reimbursement methodology as provided under the guidelines pertinent to the 
EIRP  and  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  disbursement  guidelines.17  The  imprest  account 
established for the EIRP in Dili, East Timor will be used for disbursement of the supplemental 
grant.  
 
Reporting and Accounts. Reporting requirements, accounts, and financial statements 
72. 
under the additional funding will be established as determined under the EIRP. These include 
inception  report,  quarterly  progress  reports,  audits,  draft  final  report,  and  project  completion 
report. The PMU will establish the necessary accounts in Dili, and maintain separate accounts 
for all expenditures under the EIRP-2, including its individual contracts and other components. 

                                                 
17 ADB. 2001. Loan Disbursement Handbook. Manila. 

 16 

These  bank  accounts  will  be  under  the  control  of  the  chief  technical  adviser.  The  PMU  will 
furnish  ADB  with  accounts  and  related  financial  statements  reflecting  the  accounts  for  each 
project-related  contract.  These  financial  statements  will  be  audited  using  generally  accepted 
accounting principles by auditors acceptable to ADB. The audited financial statements together 
with the auditor’s report will be forwarded to ADB within six months of the end of each related 
fiscal year. The PMU consultants will keep detailed records on the costing and expenditures of 
the project components and will assist with reporting. 
 
H. 

Environmental and Social Measures 

1. 

Environmental Impact and Social Dimensions 

The  EIRP-2 

is  classified  as  environmental  category  B.  Accordingly,  an 

initial 
73. 
environmental  examination  was  prepared  in  accordance  with  the  ADB’s  Environmental 
Guidelines for Selected Infrastructure Projects. The IEE indicates that while construction-related 
environmental  impact  is  unavoidable,  this  can  be  mitigated  using  appropriate  engineering 
practices. The IEE concludes that the EIRP-2 will result in a net benefit with costs of mitigation 
being outweighed by the envisaged benefits. The summary IEE is in Appendix 11. 

 
2. 

Poverty Reduction and Social Assessment 

74. 
The EIRP-2 is classified as a pro-poor growth intervention. An initial social assessment 
(ISA) and a poverty assessment were carried out. Significant positive impacts are expected for 
the beneficiary communities. The civil works component is expected to enhance the reliability of 
road  access  for  communities  around  the  country,  including  poor  and  vulnerable  communities. 
The establishment of a community-based road maintenance regime will provide a cost-effective 
means  for  ensuring  that  roads  are  maintained,  and  provide  a  mechanism  for  fostering 
sustainable  incomes  to  the  rural  communities  that  have  a  strong  need  for  income  generating 
opportunities. Rural communities in East Timor have a strong structure of rural representation, 
and  village  representatives  are  capable  of  organizing  collective  activity,  such  as  road 
maintenance.  The  initiative  is  supported  by  and  appropriate  to  the  local  conditions  and 
community  structures.  The  initial  social  assessment  and  poverty  assessment  are  in  Appendix 
12. 
 
I. 

Risks 

The  EIRP-2  does  not  face  any  unusual  risks.  Funding  has  been  committed  from  the 
75. 
TFET  in  the  full  amount  of    $9.0  million.  Due  to  the  limited  number  of  skilled  East  Timorese 
supervisors and engineers, the EIRP-2 is focused to provide maximum opportunities for training. 
However,  the  lack  of  an  adequate  pool  of  technically  qualified  East  Timorese  can  delay 
complete  transfer  of  the  road  agency  to  Timorese  control.  The  PMU  will  support  road  agency 
operations  and  will  seek  sustainable  solutions  for  staffing  and  training  issues.  Finally,  road 
maintenance  and  road  sector  services  can  be  justified  by  the  broad  economic  benefits  of  the 
sector,  the  road  network’s  role  inducing  economic  growth  and  development,  as  well  as  social 
necessity.  Road  maintenance  funding,  while  seen  as  expensive  in  East  Timor’s  context,  is 
recognized  by  all  stakeholders  as  necessary  to  ensure  the  selected  growth  and  social 
development  pattern  of  East  Timor.  The  EIRP-2  will  ensure  adequate  support  to  the  budget 
preparation process and to information dissemination on the importance of road maintenance. 
 

 VI. 

APPROVAL 

76. 
The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision  and  administration  by  ADB  of  a  grant  to  East  Timor,  in  an  amount  not  exceeding 
$9,000,000, to be financed by the Trust Fund for East Timor, for the Emergency Infrastructure 
Rehabilitation Project (Phase 2), and hereby reports such action to the Board.

Project Management Unit 

  
A. 
 
1. 
Specialists  engaged  under  this  consultancy  will  guide  the  management  of  the 
Emergency Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (Phase 2) (EIRP-2) to assist restoration of East 
Timor's road sector by addressing backlog and periodic maintenance needs and by establishing 
a  road  maintenance  regime  in  the  field.  The  Ministry  of  Water  and  Public  Works  (MWPW)  of 
East Timor will award road repair contracts in accordance with the Guidelines for Procurement 
Under Asian Development Bank (ADB) Loans with funding arranged by the ADB from the Trust 
Fund  for  East  Timor  (TFET).  The  consultants  will  administer  the  contracts  to  facilitate  the 
establishment  of  regional  road  maintenance  organizations.  Specific  responsibilities  are  as 
follows: 
 

The  EIRP-2  disbursements  will  use  the  imprest  account  used  under  the 
Emergency Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (EIRP).

Appropriately qualified domestic staff will be engaged for the EIRP-2 as follows: 
(a)  a  project  manager  who  will  be  counterpart  to  the  chief  technical  adviser 
(international  consultant);  (b)  a  project  accountant,  as  counterpart  to  a  financial 
and  administrative  adviser  (international  consultant);  and  (c)  road  and  bridge 
engineers as counterparts to international engineers.  

The following appropriately qualified field staff for the road sector will continue to 
be employed: (a) 4 regional engineers assigned to the four regional depots and 
subdepots  as  road  administrators  and  the  field  management  team;  (b)  road 
supervisors;  (c)  clerical  staff;  and  (d)  camp  security/cleaners.  These  will  be 
funded from the Consolidated Fund for East Timor (CFET). 

The  international  and  domestic  contractors  will  work  to  budgets  set  by  EIRP-2 
management for road works. ADB funds will be disbursed to the contractors on 
the production of appropriate measurement certificates. 

All  works  will  be  carried  out  with  significant  consideration  to  maximizing  local 
employment  opportunities,  and  rural  communities  will  be  contracted 
for 
sustainable activity establishing a continuing routine maintenance mechanism on 
their local road sections. 

Programs  will  be  implemented  that  will  upgrade  technical  capacity  of  the 
maintenance  regime  including  contractors.  After  training,  the  local  contractors 
and  road  administration  are  expected  to  be  capable  of  carrying  out  and 
supervising all normal maintenance repairs, including (a) selecting and preparing 
suitable materials for the repair activities, including small crusher operations; (b) 
patching  with  hot  and  cold  asphalt,  including  the  use  of  small  spot  mixers;  (c) 
completing  concrete  works;  (d)  laying  culverts;  (e)  installing  drainage;  (f) 
completing  stone  pitching;  (g)  constructing  gabion  retaining  walls;  and  (h) 
engaging,  organizing,  and  supervising  local  community  labor  to  carry  out 
unskilled and labor-intensive routine maintenance.

responsibility  for  the  EIRP-2  implementation  and  reporting  to  ADB,  the  project  funds,  and  the 
EIRP-2's imprest account.

as a training opportunity.

Project Implementation and Advisory Consulting Services 

 
The  PMU  will  implement  the  EIRP-2  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  guidelines.  It  will 
6. 
coordinate  with  ADB's  TA  for  transport  restoration,  restore  essential  services  in  the  three 
subsectors,  and  initiate  establishment  of  sustainable  sector  management  operations.  The 
PMU's organization chart is shown in Appendix 6. 
 
B. 
 
7. 
International  consulting  services  will  support  EIRP-2  implementation  and  strengthen  the 
PMU.  Three  individually  appointed  consultants  will  provide  these  services.  The  international 
consultants  will  (i)  assume  overall  responsibility  for  project  implementation  in  accordance  with 
ADB’s guidelines and reporting requirements; (ii) facilitate procurement of equipment and works 
as  specified  under  the  EIRP-2  and  evaluate,  select,  and  award  any  contracts  for  remedial 
works; (iii) undertake design and documentation as needed to prepare contracts; (iv) supervise 
implementation of works under these contracts; (v) train, advise, and assist the East Timorese 
PMU  staff  and  that  of  the  Department  of  Infrastructure  related  to  their  tasks;  and  (vi)  facilitate 
implementation  of  operational  issues  and  establishment  of  effective  sector  management  and 
operations. 
 
8. 
These  services  include  on-the-job  training  for  counterpart  staff,  training  in  basic  asset 
management  including  network  inventory,  maintenance  scheduling,  contract  management 
including the tender process, bid evaluation, contract administration, formulation of community 
employment  and  support  programs,  contract  supervision  and  quality  control,  performance 
monitoring,  and  financial  management.  The  consultant  will,  in  collaboration  with  ADB's  TA  for 
Transport Sector Improvement, review the proposed national operational procedures including 
sector  regulations  and  management  structures,  financial  management,  administration,  and 
procurement, and will contribute to the institutional development.  
 
9. 
About 60 person-months of consulting services are required in road maintenance, works 
and  project  management,  accounting,  cost  estimation,  contract  documentation  and 
management,  quality  control,  work  measurement  and  reporting,  and  establishing  effective 
maintenance  delivery  mechanisms  and  operations,  inventory  and  condition  assessments.  The 
terms of reference and the activities of the PMU will be fully coordinated with those of the TA for 
transport  sector  improvement,  and  maximum  complementarity  and  linkages  will  be  developed 
between  the  two  interventions.  The  PMU  will  implement  the  adopted  recommendations  of  the 
TA to establish sustainable sector management systems and operations.

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION  
 

A. 

Environmental Assessment Report 

 

1. 

Introduction 

 
1. 
Supplementary  funding  will  be  allocated  to  the  Emergency  Infrastructure  Rehabilitation 
Project (EIRP)1 to finance the Emergency Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (Phase 2) (EIRP-
2).  EIRP-2  will  support  establishing  an  effective  road  maintenance  capability  in  East  Timor  by 
undertaking earthworks and slope stabilization tasks on critical landslide hazard sites within the 
road  network,  and  a  routine  maintenance  regime  focusing  on  community  involvement.  Key 
components of EIRP-2 are (i) preventative civil works and periodic maintenance, (ii) support for 
the  establishment  of  a  routine  maintenance  regime  based  on  local  labor,  and  (iii)  training  and 
project management. 
 
2. 
The estimated cost is  $10  million.  The  Executing  Agency  is  the  Ministry  of  Water  and 
Public  Works  (MWPW)  in  East  Timor.  The  EIRP-2  will  commence  during  the  third  quarter  of 
2002 and conclude during the fourth quarter of 2003, lasting approximately 18 months.  
 
3. 
The  purpose  of  the  Summary  Initial  Environmental  Examination  (SIEE)  is  to  identify 
anticipated environmental of the EIRP-2 and the necessary mitigation measures, and to present 
recommendations for institutional requirements for the monitoring of environmental impacts. The 
relative  magnitude  of  the  identified  impacts,  and  costs  of  mitigation  are  provided  in  this 
appendix.    The  SIEE  is  prepared  on  the  basis  of  site  visits,  consultations,  and  examination  of 
secondary material prepared in East Timor between 1 to 15 March 2001. 
 

2. 
 

Project Description 

a. 

Project Type 

 
4. 
Infrastructure. The EIRP-2 will consist of slope stabilization works on critical landslide 
hazard sites within East Timor’s road network, capacity building in terms of technical assistance 
(TA)  to  establish  a  community,  labor-based,  routine  maintenance  regime,  training  of  East 
Timorese counterparts, and project management. 
 
5. 
The  environmental  screening  process  followed  the  checklists  for  reforestation  projects, 
given  in  the  Environmental  Guidelines  for  Selected  Infrastructure  Projects  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). 
 

b. 

Project Category 

 
6. 
The EIRP-2 is classified as category B; some environmental impacts may occur and an 
initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  is  to  be  undertaken.  Should  the  IEE  conclude  that  no 
significant  environmental  impacts  are  likely  to  result,  the  IEE  will  serve  as  the  completed 
environmental impact assessment for the EIRP-2.

Appendix 11 

41

c. 

Need for the Project 

 
7. 
Intense requirements are placed on the road network in East Timor, by the humanitarian 
assistance  to  inhabitants  of  towns  and  rural  areas  in  the  short  term,  and  by  the  sustainable 
economic development in the long term. Traditionally, the population is largely rural, although an 
increasing  degree  of  urbanization  occurred  during  the  previous  authorities,  particularly  in  the 
1990s. Rural dwellers are largely subsistence farmers, and suffer from widespread poverty, both 
in  terms  of  the  incidence  and  the  depth  of  poverty.  The  development  of  equitable  and 
sustainable  economic  opportunities  for  the  rural  poor  is  hampered  to  a  large  extent  by 
accessibility as, despite an extensive road network, road conditions are poor, vehicle operating 
costs  and  hence  transport  fares  are  high,  and  vehicular  access  to  markets  severely  restricted 
(some rural poor are known to walk very long distances to reach Dili or provincial markets).  
 
8. 
The provision and maintenance of a durable road network in East Timor is made difficult 
by  severe  geological  conditions,  the  considerable  extent  of  the  network  (approximately  1 
kilometer  [km]  of  road  for  each  3  square  kilometer  [km2]  of  land  area),  and  the  effects  of 
prolonged neglect in the period leading up to the referendum of 1999. This makes the task of 
managing  and  implementing  a  road  maintenance  system  a  challenge  by  any  standards, 
particularly as the management capacities are severely limited. 
 
9. 
To  support  the  future  East  Timorese  roads  authority  in  the  challenge  of  tackling  the 
backlog of road maintenance caused by recent neglect, the strategy adopted for the EIRP-2 is 
(i) to address critical areas of instability within the network whose treatment threatens to take up 
an undue proportion of resources available for maintenance, (ii) to establish an efficient routine 
maintenance  regime  that  itself  contributes  to  the  reduction  of  rural  poverty,  and  (iii)  to  provide 
capacity  building  to  help  the  future  roads  authority  to  acquire  the  necessary  managerial  and 
technical skills.

Description of the Environment 

 
12.  Many of the key features of East Timor’s environment are attributable to the fact that it is 
a small island:

The flora and fauna are more specialized, prone to suppression by the invasion

while its biodiversity is an important economic asset: a diverse array of nontimber

East Timor’s environment is also dominated by precarious geological conditions, a moist 

 
13. 
climate, and a weak institutional base for environmental management.  
 

a. 

Physical Resources 

i. 

Topography and Geology 

 
Steep  hills  and  valleys  dominate  the  terrain  within  East  Timor,  with  the  main  feature 
14. 
being a mountain ridge running east-west across the island. The island itself is situated at the 
nexus  of  four  geological  plates  and  two  continental  blocks,  and  is  formed  by  tectonic  plate 

 Appendix 11 

43

activity that resulted in a large sedimentary rock mass being lifted above sea level. Three units, 
distinguished  by  their  age  and  origins,  comprise  the  rock  mass.  The  youngest  of  these,  the 
sedimentary  rock,  dominates  the  top  rock  layers,  while  the  underlying,  older  rock  comprises 
schists,  slates,  and  shales.  The  landscape  is  characterized  by  relative  geological  youth,  the 
inherent  instability  of  the  sedimentary  rock,  and  a  high  incidence  of  folds  and  faults.  Because 
the  island  is  relatively  young,  the  uplift  process  that  has  formed  it  is  still  in  progress,  and  is 
estimated to be taking place at a rate of 10 millimeter (mm) per year.2 
 
The nature of the predominant, younger sedimentary rock is particularly relevant to the 
15. 
engineering of hill roads. These rocks feature conglomerates that are poorly consolidated, with 
weak matrices, as well as sandstone, siltstone, and weak alluvial deposits. These are variable in 
strength  and  texture,  and  prone  to  failure  triggered  by  the  ongoing  uplift  process  or  torrential 
rain, quite apart from those caused by earthworks or agriculture.  
 

ii. 

Climate 

 
 East  Timor’s  climate  is  largely  warm  and  moist,  with  considerable  variations  occurring 
16. 
with  altitude  and  the  influence  of  the  mountain  chain  on  the  distribution  of  rainfall.  Mean 
temperatures  vary  from  around  28ºC  at  sea  level  to  around  19ºC  at  the  highest  settlements, 
some 1,400 meters above sea level. The seasons are quite even, and diurnal temperatures vary 
more than mean monthly temperatures.  
 
17. 
The mountain chain intercepts precipitation, resulting in a drier zone on its northern side, 
with a wet season of some 4 to 6 months commencing around November, while the land to the 
south  experiences  two  wet  seasons,  a  major  one  of  7  to  9  months  commencing  around 
November, and an additional, briefer one, between May and August. Significantly, much of the 
rain falls in brief, torrential falls, creating periods of intense hazard to property, agriculture, and 
infrastructure from saturated soils and rapid surface water flows.  
 

b. 

Ecological Resources 

 
18. 
Documented  knowledge  on  the  plants  and  animals,  and  their  original  communities  in 
East Timor, is relatively limited, although current research on East Timor’s ecosystems suggests 
that  much  local  knowledge  is  undocumented.  Little  is  therefore  known  about  the  value,  in 
economic or conservation terms, of natural resources on the island, particularly about the uses 
and properties of indigenous and even endemic plant and animal species. However, there are 
signs  that  East  Timor  bears  a  diverse  and  unique  natural  resource  base:  Field  workers  within 
the current Government system report a high level of knowledge of uses of plants for medicinal 
and  other  purposes.  The  basic  geology  of  East  Timor  differs  from  that  of  its  neighbors  and  is 
therefore  likely  to  have  evolved  a  significantly  different  flora  and  fauna.  In  addition,  the  entire 
region,  where  land  masses  have  been  brought  together  by  tectonic  plate  movements,  is  of 
intense biogeographical interest. 
 
19. 
The lack of knowledge extends to the national park and protected areas that have been 
established in East Timor. The law that existed under previous the Indonesian regime named 15 
protected areas. Under UNTAET, these areas were protected in Regulation No. 2000/19 of 30 
June  2000,  which  also  gave  UNTAET  broader  powers  for  the  protection  of  species  and 
reserves. Accurate and reliable data as to the boundaries of the protected areas is not available,

University of New South Wales Press  

 44 

Appendix 11 

and only approximate sketches of the boundaries exist. No management plans for the various 
areas appear to have been prepared. A compendium of statistics published by the Indonesian 
Government in 1998 suggests that the total extent of projected areas is around 64,000 hectares 
(ha), which to around 4.6 percent of the total land area.  
 

i. 

Vegetation 

 
20. 
The  present  day  vegetation  cover  is  largely  influenced  by  agriculture,  land  clearance, 
and  grass  burning.  Throughout  much  of  the  island,  particularly  along  the  north  coast,  hillsides 
bear  mainly  grassland  savanna,  with  a  sparse  overstory  of  trees  such  as  Eucalyptus  sp, 
extensive  grass  growth,  a  limited  shrub  story,  and  an  absence  of  young  tree  saplings  in  most 
places. More diverse growth occurs on steep stream banks and clefts within the hill landscape. 
Where  the  vegetation  is  less  disturbed  by  human  settlement,  a  range  of  forest  types  occur 
mainly reflecting the rainfall distribution patterns. In driest areas to the north of the island, thorn 
forest  occurs,  giving  way  to  dry  deciduous  forest  in  much  of  the  coastal  land.  Mountain  areas 
feature  moist  deciduous  forest,  with  evergreen  rainforest  occurring  in  pockets.  Roadside 
vegetation,  particularly  in  the  northern  part  of  the  island,  features  a  high  level  of  invasion  by 
aggressive  exotic  weed  species,  e.g,  Tithonia  diversifolia  and  Lantana  camara,  both  common 
noxious weed species with an extremely wide distribution. 
 

ii. 

Fauna 

 
21. 
The island’s fauna includes both indigenous and introduced species. The main threat to 
the populations of indigenous species, is the loss of the habitat in which they evolved. Extensive 
conversion of forestland since early colonial occupation has therefore resulted in reductions of 
the  populations  of  indigenous  fauna  species.  Introduced  animals  include  deer,  civets,  and 
rodents; a number of Australian bird species have also been introduced.  
 
A number of rare species of interest occur among the island’s mammal, bird, insect, and 
22. 
fish  populations.  The  scientific  interest  in  the  fauna  of  East  Timor  and  its  island  neighbors, 
although little studied, is intensified by the fact that two major biogeographical regions, Oriental 
and  Australian,  meet  in  the  region.  Separated  during  early  geological  time,  the  two  regions 
developed quite distinct fauna. Although the fauna are understood to have merged, in terms of 
species  composition,  as  the  two  regions  came  together,  significant  differences  continue  to  be 
observed.  
 

c. 

Marine Ecosystems 

 
23. 
A  number  of  marine  ecosystems  can  be  found  around  the  immediate  coast  of  East 
Timor,  namely  coral  reefs  and  seagrass  beds,  with  mangrove  forests,  rocky  sea  bottoms,  and 
muddy flats in the intertidal zone. While a significant fishing industry has never developed in the 
country,  these  ecosystems  are  of  considerable  scientific  and  conservation  value.  Many  of  the 
creatures of such ecosystems are vulnerable to changes in water turbidity caused by sediment 
deposition.  
 

d. 

Human and Economic Development 

 
24. 
The status of human and economic development in East Timor has largely been shaped 
by  Portuguese  colonization,  between  1562  and  1974,  and  also  by  the  ensuing  Indonesian 
occupation until late 1999. Early Portuguese colonists established trade in commodities such as 
sandalwood, timber, honey, and beeswax. Consistent with the actions of many colonial powers 

 Appendix 11 

45

of  the  period,  little  effort  was  made  to  curb  overexploitation  and  reserves  of  sandalwood  and 
possibly certain timber species were brought to near extinction by the early 1900s. During the 
four  centuries  of  Portuguese  colonization,  Catholicism  became  the  dominant  religion,  and  a 
colonial  system  of  administration  was  established.  The  Portuguese  colonial  period  ended  in 
1974,  and  the  Indonesian  government  took  power  following  an  invasion  in  1975.  While 
Indonesia  invested  in  the  nation’s  infrastructure,  much  of  this  appears  to  have  been  for  the 
purpose of countering local resistance to their occupation. To facilitate the control of resistance 
among tribal groups, particularly in remote areas, the Indonesian government built an extensive 
road  network,  and  allegedly  imposed  migration  of  tribal  people  within  East  Timor  so  as  to 
fragment traditional group structures and weaken resistance. The Indonesian occupation came 
to  an  end  in  late  1999  when  a  referendum  demonstrated  that  most  East  Timorese  wanted 
complete  independence  from  Indonesia.  This  result  triggered  intense  violence  that  led  to 
numerous  deaths,  and  the  decimation  of  the  country’s  infrastructure  and  services,  with 
widespread  destruction  of  public  buildings  and  utilities  as  well  as  private  homes.  With  the 
installation  of  UNTAET  in  September  1999,  an  emergency  rehabilitation  effort  has  ensued, 
focusing  primarily  on  restoring  infrastructure  required  to  distribute  humanitarian  aid  and  on 
redeveloping  durable  infrastructure  and  the  capacity  for  its  maintenance.  As  of  20  May  2002, 
UNTAET  has  handed  the  administration  over  to  an  indigenous  Government  and  a  reduced 
United  Nations  Mission  in  East  Timor  has  been  agreed  to  be  retained  to  ensure  inability  and 
political stability of East Timor. 
 
25. 
East Timor has always been poor and was one of the poorest parts of Indonesia, itself a 
poor  country.  Indonesia’s  own  economic  performance  was  influenced  by  the  Asian  financial 
crisis  in  the  late  1990s,  which,  with  the  fall  of  the  rupiah,  led  to  very  low  incomes  for  East

The  anticipated  negative  environmental  impacts  are  associated  primarily  with  the

number  of  positive  environmental  impacts  are  associated  with  the  EIRP-2.  The  magnitude  of 
impacts and mitigation measures have been evaluated in quantitative and qualitative terms for 
purposes of project selection, and to identify environmental costs.  
 

b. 

Overview of Environmental Impacts and Issues 

 
34. 
In  focusing  on  the  amelioration  of  major  landslide  sites  and  efficient  road  maintenance 
the  EIRP-2  is  by  nature  an  environmentally  friendly  initiative.  The  screening  process  has  not 
yielded any effects that may cause it to carry undue environmental cost.  
 
35. 
Potentially, the EIRP-2 has highly significant indirect environmental benefits. It also has 
potential for setting national standards as an intervention directed to reduce impact of erosion 
and,  particularly,  through  the  management  mechanism  implemented  to  mitigate  construction-
associated  environmental  impact.  These  standards  can  be  set  through  rigorous  contract 
supervision to ensure high standards of performance by the contractor, in terms of adherence to 
the  principle  of  best  practice.  Contractors  will  ensure  a  high  standard  of  environmental 

 Appendix 11 

47

management and safety in their work, and will substantially mitigate most construction effects, 
as well as effects associated with maintenance. 
 
36. 
One very important aspect of the principle of best practice is the issue of side tipping of 
spoil material. Although widespread in hilly areas throughout Asia, the practice of side tipping of 
excavated  material  or  landslip  material  is  extremely  damaging.  Loose  spoil  deposited  on 
hillsides rapidly forms rills and gullies, which concentrate runoff water causing gullies to expand 
and  cut  into  the  original  ground.  The  effect  is  made  worse  by  the  smothering  of  vegetation, 
which plays an important part in slope protection and stabilization. As it travels downstream, the 
spoil  increases  sediment  load  and  erosive  power  of  waterways,  potentially  damaging  aquatic 
ecosystems and agriculture as well.  
 
The  effects  of  side  tipping  can  be  mitigated  against  by  ensuring  that  all  loose  material 
37. 
arising from excavations or from the clearance of landslips is transported to safe tip sites where 
it can be retained, and even used as a productive growing medium. The total cost of mitigation 
for the EIRP-2 is tentatively estimated, in part II of this report at under $50,000. This represents 
a  very  minor  addition  to  the  project  cost.  In  the  long  term,  the  institution  of  good  spoil 
management  will  set  high  national  standards,  for  which,  at  present,  there  is  little  precedent  in 
Asia.

3. 

Valuation of Impacts 

 
47. 
The EIRP-2 targets to control of major and minor slope failure hazards to minimize their 
effect on the integrity of the transport network and the environment as a whole. The valuation of 
benefits  is  based  on  the  expected  quantities  and  values  associated  with  the  with-project 
scenario,  compared  with  the  expected  environmental  consequences  of  the  without-project 
scenario. For the with-project scenario, under which no special attention is expected to be given 
to  preventing  slope  failures,  uncertainty  exists  as  to  the  precise  scale  and  frequency  of  slope 
failures,  the  level  of  resources  and  effectiveness  of  preventative  measures  available,  and  the 
quantity  and  nature  of  environmental  damage  caused  by  stressors  such  as  landslide  slip 
material. This valuation exercise compares and contrasts the anticipated environmental benefits 
and costs using both qualitative and quantitative estimates. The approach taken is therefore to 
evaluate  project  benefits  mainly  qualitatively,  to  estimate  the  cost  of  mitigation  of  adverse 
environmental impacts that would arise as a result of the EIRP-2, and to quantify any residual 
negative  environmental  impacts  as  far  as  possible.  To  estimate  mitigation  costs,  a  set  of 
assumptions for locations and quantities of project work has been made. These are summarized 
in para. 87 of this appendix.

49. 
The direct environmental benefit envisaged from this work is the protection of land that is 
at  risk  to  damage  from  landslides.  This  is  highly  significant.  In  addition,  there  are  indirect 
benefits  associated  with  the  retention  of  material  that  would  otherwise  be  released  into 
watersheds  as  a  result  of  the  landslides.  These  include  the  prevention  of  damage  to 
ecosystems,  and  agricultural  and  residential  land  through  sediment  transport  in  flood  and 
stream flows; and the effects on marine ecosystems of the release of soil particles into the sea.  
 
50. 
The receptors of soil and rock debris from landslides are terrestrial ecosystems, marine 
ecosystems,  farms,  and  homes.  In  view  of  the  occurrence  of  naturally  occurring  landslips

51

triggered  by  ongoing  uplift  of  the  island  and  severe  storm  events,  affected  ecosystems,  both 
terrestrial  and  marine,  have  likely  evolved  under  conditions  of  repeated  deposition  of  soil  and 
rock debris produced by landslides. In view of this, no significant impact on receptor ecosystems 
is envisaged. 
 
51. 
In  the  case  of  both  farms  and  homes,  severe  risks  are  associated  with  occasional 
landslide events. Potentially severe landslide areas will likely be successfully treated under the 
EIRP-2. Any single successful treatment of a potential landslide is likely to prevent catastrophic 
loss of productive land and homes downstream. The effects on both agricultural productivity and 
private  homes  is  therefore  highly  significant.  While  the  location  and  extent  of  damage  to  land 
and  property  cannot  be  reliably  predicted,  the  cost  of  road  reinstatement  alone  following  such 
an  event  is  likely  to  exceed  $100,000.  The  environmental  cost  is  therefore  rated  as  highly 
significant. 
 

ii. 

Effects of Improved Routine Maintenance 

 
Under  the  EIRP-2,  a  routine  maintenance  regime  will  be  established  that  will  seek  to 
52. 
involve  communities  in  organizing  and  carrying  out  routine  maintenance  work.  Such  a  regime 
will  potentially  result  in  improved  vigilance  and  more  rapid  corrective  action  for  incipient 
problems  such  as  drain  blockages,  undercutting  of  retaining  walls,  and  pot-hole  development. 
This  rapid  corrective  action  to  incipient  problems  will  lower  the  incidence  of  larger  problems 
such  as  gully  formation  and  the  scouring  out  of  structures.  Besides  reducing  the  cost  of 
maintenance  of  the  road  network,  this  will  also  result  in  reductions  in  the  release  of  spoil  into 
watersheds. The impact on agricultural productivity and rural homes is rated as significant. The 
increased cost of repair to the road in the absence of an efficient maintenance system may be 
high in the medium and long term, in the order of $10,000 to $100,000.

b. 

Mitigated Adverse Impacts 

 

i. 

Generation of Spoil from Construction 

 
57. 
Description of impacts if not mitigated. The total volume of spoil to be produced by 
the  EIRP-2  is  estimated  at  4,200  cubic  meters  (m3).  This  spoil,  if  released  down  slope  from 
project sites, will act as a stressor to the environment. Principal receptors of the stressors will be 
small  farmers  and  landowners  within  the  watershed,  any  protected  areas  and  the  marine 
ecosystem where the spoil is finally released into the sea. 
 
Assuming terrestrial and marine ecosystems have evolved under conditions where such 
58. 
landslides are commonplace, the cost of release of landslide soil and debris on forest and park 
land, and into the sea is considered negligible. However, spoil arising from the project work and 
from  relatively  minor  landslips  occurring  during  the  project  period  will  both  affect  property  and 
productive land downstream, and increase the risk of further slope failures.  
 
59. 
The  effects  of  side  tipping  on  hill  roads  generally  are  widely  apparent  throughout  Asia 
and  the  Pacific.  Tipped  material  smothers  vegetation,  which  is  often  playing  a  crucial  role  in 
supporting the slope. The material rapidly forms rills and gullies, which cut into the slopes, often 
below the original surface level. In more fragile hill areas, such as those in East Timor, this gully 
formation is capable of triggering substantial failures.  
 
In the absence of information on location, frequency, and magnitude of sites where side 
60. 
tipping  will  occur,  the  cost  of  this  practice  may  best  be  assessed  by  means  of  a  large-scale 
monitoring  program,  perhaps  with  research  sites  in  several  countries.  However,  in  view  of  the 
fact  that  this  practice  can  cause  severe  additional  failures,  the  cost  of  uncontrolled  tipping  is 
therefore,  potentially  in  excess  of  the  cost  of  rectification  of  further  failures.  This  may  exceed 
$100,000 over the life of the EIRP-2. 
 
61. 
Cost of mitigation. The effects of spoil generation can be mitigated by haulage of spoil 
to approved tip sites, where slopes are not at risk to damage from the effects of deposited spoil. 
 
62. 
Based on the key assumptions (paras. 89-90) volumes of soil and soft rock excavation 
can be estimated, for the EIRP and the EIRP-2. Based on observations made during site visits 
during the IEE mission, spoil must be hauled distances of 1 to 30 kilometers (km) between the 
source and a suitable tip site.  
 
63. 
Assuming heavy trucks will be used for the haulage of spoil, and that these can carry 5 
cubic meters of spoil, the cost can be estimated using vehicle operating cost data given in the 
Feasibility  Study  for  the  Transport  Sector  Restoration  Project.9  These  data  show  that  the  unit

if  planting  stock  is  gathered  from  a  single  source  area,  or  if  weed  species  are  used  for 
bioengineering measures. 
 
68.  When  planting  material  such  as  grass  or  shrub  cuttings  or  seeds  are  gathered  from  a 
single area, damage can arise as a result both of removal of vegetation and disturbance of the 
soil.  In  both  cases,  particularly  in  steep  locations  where  the  work  sites  will  be  located,  the 
removal of plants and consequent soil disturbance may result in minor slope failures, particularly 
if root stock is being collected. The risk of environmental damage is therefore significant.  
 
69. 
In  general,  good  plants  for  bioengineering  will  be  vigorous,  firm  rooting,  and  hardy. 
These  properties  are  largely  shared  by  invasive  weed  species  that,  if  used  prolifically  for 
bioengineering,  serve  to  increase  the  seed  source  of  these  plants  and  deepen  their 
establishment in the area, at the expense of indigenous and even endemic species. In an island 
situation such as East Timor, this effect can be significant.  
 
70. 
Cost  of  mitigation.  Two  mitigation  measures  are  identified,  (i)  carrying  out  all  plant 
propagation  in  nurseries,  and  (ii)  engaging  a  plant  ecologist  to  carry  out  investigations  and 
provide recommendations as to species to use and means of propagation. 
 
71. 
Nursery sites will need to be within some 50 km of work sites, and therefore three sites 
are  likely  to  be  required  for  the  EIRP-2,  one  to  serve  the  Batugade  to  Zumalai  road,  one  to 
serve the Tibar to Ermera road, and one to serve the Baucau to Viqueque road. The total area 
of  planting  envisaged  (11,000  m2)  is  not  great,  but  plants  should  also  be  available  for  the 
maintenance program as well. 50 m2 of grass and shrub beds in each nursery will be adequate. 
The total land requirement for each of these nurseries will be some 200 m2, to include walkways 
around each bed, and adequate siting for a small shed and water tank. The costs anticipated for 
each nursery are given in Table A11.2.

iii. 

Effects of Quarrying and Borrowing 

The  total  estimated  volume  of  material  to  be  sourced  from  quarries  and  borrow  pits 

 
75. 
Description of impacts if not mitigated. All quarries and borrow pits will probably be 
located in hilly terrain, the baseline risk to slope failures is high. Excavation activities will leave 
steep walls around each quarry or borrow pit site, which will be in a less stable state than it was 
prior  to  excavation,  particularly  where  quarry  or  pit  walls  are  composed  of  soil,  or  contain  soil 
cuts. This will result in possible collapse of the quarry pit site, causing land-take and the release 
of spoil into watersheds. Such impacts are potentially significant. 
 
76. 
Cost of mitigation. Bioengineering techniques may be used to rehabilitate quarry and 
borrow  pit  sites,  assuming  that  excavation  operations  are  supervised  to  ensure  that  walls  are 
left at an even angle.  
 
77. 
(paras. 96-97) are 
 
stone for gabion: 6,500 m3, and  
graded material for wall backfill: 4,475 m3. 
 
Assuming quarries and borrow pits are situated on slopes, the area of quarry walls to be 
78. 
rehabilitated  can  be  assumed  to  be  approximately  equal  to  the  volume  of  material  to  be 
removed. The total area to be rehabilitated is therefore estimated at approximately 11,000 m2.  
 
A suitable method of quarry rehabilitation is the seeding of slopes using grass and shrub 
79. 
seed,  followed  by  the  placement  of  a  mulch,  held  in  place  with  netting.  Based  on  discussions 
held  with  resource  people  involved  in  construction  and  planting  activities  in  East  Timor,  a  unit 
rate ranging from $0.20 to $0.70 per m2 is envisaged. Thus, the total cost of quarry and borrow 
pit rehabilitation is expected to range between $2,200 and $15,400. 
 

c. 

General Mitigation Measures: Training 

 
The supervising engineers will bear the responsibility of ensuring that contractors adhere 
80. 
to  their  environmental  and  safety  plans,  as  well  as  to  international  standards  of  construction 
management.  To  ensure  that  the  capacity  exists  for  this  function,  during  the  EIRP-2  and 
subsequently,  a  core  team  of  counterpart  staff  should  receive  training,  both  at  international 
institutions  and  on-the-job,  in  supervision  and  monitoring  of  the  performance  of  contractors  in 
compliance with environmental standards (Table A11.4).
