INTIAL SOCIAL AND POVERTY ANALYSIS 
 

Introduction 

Project Description 

A. 
 
The  Emergency  Infrastructure  Rehabilitation  Project  (Phase  2)  (EIRP-2)  will  follow  the 
1. 
existing Emergency Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (EIRP), being implemented under Grant 
8181-ETM.  It  will  address  key  concerns  for  establishing  an  effective  road  maintenance 
capability  in  East  Timor,  by  undertaking  slope  stabilization  tasks  on  critical  landslide  hazard 
sites  within  the  road  network,  and  provide  support  for  the  establishment  of  a  routine 
maintenance regime, focusing on community involvement. 
 
2. 
The  purpose  of  this  report  is  to  summarize  the  approach  and  findings  of  a  social  and 
poverty assessment of the EIRP-2, conducted during April 2001. The investigations consisted of 
key informant interviews, questionnaire surveys of the principal beneficiary groups, and review 
of secondary information sources. In addition, semiformal meetings were held with beneficiary 
groups to obtain opinions, views, and wishes of key stakeholders for use in project design.  
 
B. 
 
3. 
The  EIRP-2  is  an  infrastructure  development  initiative  and  will  consist  of  slope 
stabilization works on critical landslide hazard sites within East Timor’s road network, capacity 
building in terms of technical assistance (TA) for the establishment of a community labor-based 
routine maintenance regime, training of East Timorese counterparts, and project management. 
Project  sites  are  located  on  selected  priority  road  links  throughout  East  Timor,  comprising  the 
road lengths between Batugade and Zumalai in Bobonaro and Cova Lima districts in the west of 
the country, Tibar to Ermera in Liquica and Ermera districts to the west of Dili, and Baucau to 
Viqueque towns in Baucau and Viqueque districts toward the east of the country. The total road 
length covered is 211.4 kilometers (km), and total EIRP-2 cost is estimated at $10 million. 
 
4. 
The  need  for  the  EIRP-2  arises  from  both  the  key  role  of  road  access  in  extending 
services and market access to the rural poor of East Timor, and the difficulties encountered in 
maintaining roads at reasonable cost in the severe geological conditions prevalent on the island. 
The population of East Timor is largely rural, and limitations on access to schools, hospitals and 
markets  both  exacerbate  poor  living  conditions  and  limit  opportunities  for  poverty  eradication. 
The reliability of road access is limited by the frequency of landslide occurrence, which is largely 
due to the weak materials of which most slopes are composed, and high, concentrated rainfall 
rendering  much  of  the  primary  road  network  highly  vulnerable  to  failure.  The  expense  and 
technical  difficulty  involved  in  repairing  and  preventing  landslides  threatens  to  deflect  vital 
resources from routine road repair and maintenance over primary and secondary roads, which 
is essential if vehicle operating costs, and hence accessibility of roads to use by poorer groups, 
are  to  decrease.  The  strategy  adopted  for  the  EIRP-2  is  to  address  critical  areas  of  instability 
within the network, to establish an efficient routine maintenance regime that itself contributes to 
the  reduction  of  rural  poverty,  along  with  capacity  building  to  help  the  future  roads  authority 
acquire the necessary managerial and technical skills. 
 
5. 
The establishment of a community-based routine road maintenance regime is of special 
relevance  to  the  social  and  poverty  assessment,  as  a  specific  pro-poor  aspect  of  the  project 
design.

C. 
 

Country Background 

1. 

Social Issues 

 
9. 
East Timor is currently in a postconflict situation, following the events associated with a 
referendum held in late 1999, in which the people of East Timor voted overwhelmingly in favor 
of  independence  from  Indonesia.  The  referendum  prompted  widespread  and  severe  violence 
that  resulted  in  many  deaths,  the  destruction  of  public  infrastructure  and  private  property,  and 
the  loss  of  many  skilled  and  professional  people.  However,  the  referendum  succeeded  in 
removing the former administration, which had become intensely unpopular with the majority of 
East Timorese.  
 
10. 
The  current  transition  period  and  forthcoming  elections  offer  both  opportunities  and 
challenges. The new leaders who are to be elected in 2001 have the opportunity to benefit from 
the  lessons  learned  by  other  Asian  and  Pacific  countries  who  have  experienced  significant 
structural  changes  in  government  in  recent  decades.  In  addition,  the  lessons  learned  from 
varying  approaches  to  social  and  economic  development  in  developing  countries  can  also  be 
brought into consideration as the new government forms strategies for the development of the 
new  nation.  At  the  same  time,  most  East  Timorese  have  high  expectations  from  the  new 
government, while real improvements for the majority of East Timorese will take time to achieve. 
In  addition,  the  country’s  new  leaders  will  be  elected  from  a  group  that  has  been  denied  the 
benefit of experience in governance during the former regime. 
 

2. 

Poverty Issues 

 
11. 
Poverty in  East  Timor  is,  at  present, very widespread, particularly in rural areas. While 
many  of  the  rural  poor  are  able  to  avoid  severe  food  shortages,  daily  expenses  such  as 
transportation  and  essential  goods  are  high,  and  opportunities  for  income  generation  limited. 
According to available data,1 some 75 percent of the population are poor; their average income 
is  some  7  percent  below  the  poverty  line.  Measures  of  inequality  currently  suggest  limited 
disparity between the relatively well off and the poor. 
 
12. 
Poverty has always been widespread in East Timor, but has been exacerbated both by 
the  events  of  late  1999,  and  by  a  preceding  period  of  deepening  neglect  of  social  and  other 
infrastructure by the previous government.  
 
13. 
Though security was restored by mid 2000 and some public services set up by the East 
Timor  Transitional  Administration  (ETTA),  the  effects  of  the  violence  and  destruction,  which 
included  the  removal  of  access  to  Indonesian  domestic  markets,  combined  with  the  period  of 
neglect by the previous government, led to a considerably worsened poverty situation.  
 
14. 
In  comparison  with  the  situation  prior  to  the  referendum,  the  rural  poor  of  East  Timor 
suffer from higher costs of transportation and essential goods such as clothing and fuel. Many 
are living in damaged houses, or in crowded conditions as a result of the destruction of private 
homes.  While  the  ETTA  has  reestablished  many  schools  and  set  up  health  services,  both  of 
these  services  are  relatively  understaffed.  Health  conditions  appear  to  be  deteriorating,  with  a 

                                                 
1  The  most  up  to  date  information  source  at  present  is  the  survey  carried  out  under  the  ADB  funded  East  Timor 
Rapid  Assessment  of  Economic  and  Social  Conditions  report  of  June  2000.  This  is  expected  to  be  updated  by 
June 2001, following completion and analysis of a more substantial survey. 

 

 74 

Appendix 12 

high incidence of malaria and lower respiratory tract infections, in particular. School curricula are 
generally limited to language training. Of primary significance is the lack of income generating 
opportunities for the poor. While East Timorese have been largely able to avoid starvation, by 
finding  alternative  food  sources  as  well  as  benefits  from  food  distribution  by  relief  agencies, 
economic  activity,  particularly  at  the  village  level,  remains  extremely  limited.  Most  rural 
households have little or no access to cash-earning employment. Meagre surpluses of fruits and 
vegetables  are  often  exchanged  for  other  produce  in  local  markets,  rather  than  for  cash.  The 
removal  of  trade  with  neighboring  Indonesian  provinces  has  meant  that  many  of  the 
commodities  that  were  previously  sold  in  Dili  no  longer  fetch  prices  that  suffice  to  cover 
transport  costs.  Beyond  coffee  and  some  handicrafts,  few  commodities  can  easily  be  sold 
internationally, and opportunities for producing these are relatively localized. With little access to 
cash-generating  opportunities,  access  to  credit  is  minimal  and  hence  the  means  to  establish 
small businesses or seek employment further afield. 
 
15. 
Reduced export opportunities and increasing migration to the towns from the countryside 
has resulted in growing urban poverty, particularly in Dili. The urban poor share with their rural 
neighbors the situation of worsening health, limited education, and limited opportunities. 
 
16. 
Potential  for  economic  growth  exists  through  agricultural  crop  development,  the 
sustainable  exploitation  of  assets  such  as  oil  and  gas  reserves,  and  tourism.  As  improved 
governance  evolves  in  East  Timor  and  strategies  for  economic  growth  are  identified  and 
implemented,  the  distribution  of  wealth  will  remain  a  challenge.  A  significant  means  of 
empowering  groups  such  as  the  rural  poor  to  take  part  in  growing  economic  activity  is  the 
encouragement  of  activities  that  involve  sustainable  cash  incomes  to  the  poorest  members  of 
Timorese society, which empowers people with the ability to establish small businesses, search 
for work opportunities, and have improved access to the media. 
 

3. 

Community Involvement in the Road Sector 

 
17. 
Roadside  communities  in  East  Timor  have  been  involved  in  road  maintenance  in  the 
past. Some lighter work, such as the clearance of vegetation from road drains and verges, was 
often  undertaken  on  an  unpaid  basis,  and  organized  by  the  Chefs  de  Sucos.  In  addition,  a 
number of villagers were employed by the former Department of Infrastructure, or occasionally 
by  contractors,  in  road  maintenance  tasks.  A  number  of  villagers  have  relevant  skills  such  as 
plant operators, mechanics, masons, and site supervisors. 
 
D. 
 
18. 
As a road project, the EIRP-2 will benefit all road users, and groups reliant on the regular 
passage  of  goods  and  people  for  their  livelihoods  and  quality  of  life.  The  generation  of 
employment  on  a  sustained  basis,  particularly  in  rural  areas  traversed  by  the  roads,  provides 
valuable  opportunities  for  poor  rural  communities.  In  addition,  the  establishment  of  a  cost-
effective  road  maintenance  regime,  together  with  capacity-building  functions,  will  enhance  the 
governance of the sector. Stakeholders are listed in Table A12.2.

a. 

Socioeconomic Profile of Rural Communities 

 
22.

of  the  Baucau–Viqueque  and  Batugade–Zumalai  roads  were  determined  by  means  of  a

23. 
The communities, in the case of both roads, are generally poor, have little access to paid 
employment,  are  poorly  educated,  and  often  live  in  inadequate  housing.  Relatively  few 
respondents  (49  percent)  were  able  or  willing  to  provide  data  on  incomes.  On  careful 
questioning  by  the  survey  team,  the  main  reason  for  this  appeared  to  be  a  lack  of  education, 
and  hence  familiarity  in  considering  financial  issues  on  other  than  a  day-to-day  basis.  The 
income  data  that  was  provided,  is  therefore  most  likely  to  be  a  reflection  of  the  better-off 
households.  
 
24. 
The average income for households in the survey area is around Rp623,800 (Rp976,000 
for  Baucau–Viqueque  and  Rp330,300  for  Batugade–Zumalai).  However,  most  income  is 
dependant  on  travel  to  nearby  towns  or  to  Dili  for  sale  of  goods  or  employment.  Households 
spend  on  average  some  Rp57,700  per  month  on  transport  (37,000  for  Baucau–Viqueque  and 
Rp66,000 for Batugade–Zumalai).  
 
The  survey  found  that  between  50  and  60  percent  of  these  households  are  poor.  Two

b. 

Needs and Demands of Rural Communities 

Villagers  were  asked  about  road  usage,  needs  for  improved  road  access,  and  general 

 
26. 
developmental priorities.  
 
27. 
The  most  common  problem  associated  with  road  usage  is  landslides:  62  percent  of  all 
respondents  cited  landslides  as  a  problem,  and  33  percent  cited  washouts  as  a  problem.  In 
addition,  33  percent  of  respondents  identified  inadequate  road  width  as  a  problem,  and  29 
percent cited road roughness as a problem. 
 
28. 
Nearly  all  villagers  use  the  road  frequently  to  travel  to  the  nearest  district  town,  to  Dili, 
and to other destinations. Seventy-five percent of all journeys are taken by bus, the balance by 
private vehicles, on foot, or occasionally on horseback. The most common reported purpose of 
travel is to visit friends and family, particularly on trips to Dili (63 percent of all journeys to Dili). 
Twenty-five  percent  of  journeys  are  to  district  towns  and  14  percent  of  journeys  to  Dili  are  for 
selling produce. 
 
29. 
Rising  transport  fares  are  clearly  a  major  concern  of  villagers  living  along  the  project 
roads. Eighty percent of respondents said that fares are unduly expensive, usually adding that 
fares are more expensive than under the previous government.  
 
30.  When asked for the most important requirement for an improved standard of living, the 
most common response was that sources of cash income are needed (29 percent), 22 percent 
cited  house  repairs  as  the  most  important  requirement,  and  25  percent  cited  electricity  as  the 
most  important.  Other  requirements  were  clean  water,  improved  health,  improved  education, 
and  improved  transportation  (11  percent).  When  asked  which  change  would  have  the  most 
significant  benefit  to  the  well-being  of  the  household,  again  the  most  common  response 
concerned cash earning opportunities (44 percent).

This implies an inflation rate of 24 percent over the period.

c. 

Rural Communities’ Willingness to Pay for Improved Road Services 

 
31. 
Villagers were asked if they were willing to pay for the use of roads if they own, or plan 
to own a car or motorcycle. In fact, only one respondent owned a vehicle. Fifty (85 percent) of 
the  fifty-nine  respondents  said  they  would  be  willing  to  pay  for  road  use  despite  not  owning  a 
vehicle; 9 of these (15 percent) said they were not. On average, respondents were prepared to 
pay around Rp3,500 for road use per journey. 
 

d. 

Opinions of Rural Communities 

 
32. 
The  opinions  of  villagers  were  sought  in  the  questionnaires  as  to  the  standard  of 
governance  of  the  road  sector  prior  to  1999,  and  in  village  meetings  for  the  appropriate 
arrangements for community-based road maintenance.  
 
33. 
Respondents were asked to state their opinions regarding the construction of new roads, 
standard  of  maintenance,  ability  to  treat  potholes  and  small  problems  with  roads,  ability  to  re-
open  roads  after  landslides,  employment  of  local  people  and  public  information.  For  each  of 
these aspects of road sector management, the balance of respondents were satisfied with the 
performance of the previous road authority. Respondents were most satisfied (77 percent) with 
the  extent  of  new  road  construction,  and  least  satisfied  (61  percent)  with  the  standard  of 
provision of information concerning roads to the public.  
 
34. 
Eighty-six  percent  of  all  respondents  are  prepared  to  be  involved  in  community-based 
road  work.  Seventy  percent  stated  that  they  should  be  paid  for  this  work.  During  village 
meetings,  villagers  explained  that  some  road  maintenance  work,  primarily  the  clearance  of 
vegetation,  was  organized  by  community  leaders  (chefs  de  sucos)  and  carried  out  voluntarily. 
Villagers  were  also  engaged  to  undertake  drain  clearance  and  other  heavier  tasks,  either  by 
contractors or directly by the former Department of Infrastructure. When asked what a fair rate 
of  pay  would  be  for  this  work,  the  average  daily  wage  quoted  was  Rp40,260  (Rp38,500  for 
Baucau–Viqueque and Rp41,250 for Batugade–Zumalai).  
 
35. 
Nearly all villagers felt that community-based road maintenance should be organized by 
the community leaders, usually the chefs de sucos. These individuals are considered capable of 
organizing  labor,  collecting  and  distributing  pay,  appointing  site  supervisors,  and  resolving 
conflicts.  In  some  cases  the  engagement  of  small-scale  contractors  from  among  the  general 
village  population  was  recommended,  but  these  contractors  should  be  local.  Even  where 
villagers suggest that small-scale contractors be used, the chef de suco is identified as the main 
authority for conflict resolution. Villagers feel they should be provided with hand tools, and that 
they  can  take  responsibility  for  them,  although  ultimate  responsibility  for  looking  after  tools 
provided by the road authority would rest with the chef de suco.  
 
36.  Most  communities  stressed  that  they  do  not  wish  work  in  their  neighborhood  to  be 
undertaken by people from outside their own community.  

 
3. 

Local Contractors 

 
37. 
Small-scale  local  contractors  stand  to  benefit  from  construction  and  maintenance  work 
associated with both the civil works and maintenance system establishment components of the 
EIRP-2. On discussion with communities, community work was found to often be organized by 
the  chef  de  suco,  although  in  some  places,  such  as  Maliana  (Bobonaro  District),  other 
individuals  within  the  community  are  known  to  work  as  contractors.  In  each  case  however, 

 

 Appendix 12 

79

villagers  envisaged  a  key  role  for  the  chef  de  suco  or  other  elected  representative  in  the 
execution  of  small-scale  contracts.  The  needs,  demands,  and  opinions  of  village  groups  are 
therefore taken to cover the point of view of local contractors. 
 

4. 

Commercial Transport Service Providers 

 
38. 
Bus  and  minivan  operators,  as  well  as  freight  vehicle  operators,  stand  to  benefit  both 
from the increased reliability of the road that is expected to result from the EIRP-2, and from the 
arrest  of  deterioration  of  road  surfaces.  Information  on  needs,  demands,  and  opinions  of 
transport service providers was canvassed through a questionnaire survey of vehicle operators. 
 

a. 

Needs, Demands and Opinions of Vehicle Operators 

 
39. 
The  most  common  problem  with  the  road  network  cited  by  vehicle  operators  was  the 
occurrence of blockages, resulting from landslides. Eighty-nine percent of respondents identified 
this  problem.  Concern  was  also  expressed  over  the  roughness  and  the  width  of  the  roads, 
although no respondents appeared to feel that road safety was a problem. When asked about 
requirements for the improvement of the road network, most respondents felt that roads should 
be smoother, or clear of potholes (70 percent felt this improvement is important), 65 percent felt 
that  roads  should  be  wider,  and  54  percent  felt  that  the  incidence  of  landslides  should  be 
reduced.  
 
40. 
The main concerns of vehicle operators concerned the effect of delays on their business. 
Others said that they were concerned about a growth in traffic volume. Many operators felt that 
the incidence of potholes and of landslides is increasing. 
 

b. 

Vehicle Operators’ Willingness to Pay for Road Use 

 
Ninety-five  percent  of  vehicle  operators  stated  that  they  were  prepared  to  pay  for  road 
41. 
use,  the  remaining  5  percent  stated  that  they  were  not.  Of  those  that  were  prepared  to  pay, 
some preferred to pay on the basis of a road toll for each journey undertaken (23 percent of all 
respondents), others preferred to pay periodically (57 percent of all respondents). 
 
42. 
Rp50,000 per journey undertaken, the average toll was Rp20,000. 
 
43.

5. 

Community Works 

 
44. 
At present, roads in East Timor are managed by the Ministry of Water and Public Works 
(MWPW). The future roads administration stands to benefit from the EIRP-2 in terms of reduced 
load on the road maintenance budget, and capacity building. Following the village meetings and 
survey, a workshop was held with MWPW Road Services to present the findings of the survey 
and meetings, and to discuss options for establishing community-based road maintenance.  
 
45. 
The  MWPW  Road  Services  personnel  feel  that  community-based  road  maintenance 
work  should  be  organized  by  means  of  contracts.  The  contracts  may  be  signed  with  village 
representatives  such  as  the  chef  de  suco.  The  scope  of  the  contracts  should  be  limited  to 
technically simple routine work, such as the clearance of vegetation and digging out of drains.

The  chef  de  suco  is  traditionally  responsible  for  organizing  community  work;  this  is 
considered  responsibility  to  the  community,  rather  than  financial  reward,  as  in  the  case  of  a 
contract. The wisdom of engaging chefs de suco as contractors that receive financial reward for 
organizing labor was discussed, as in the long term the element of financial reward could affect 
the  nature  of  the  chef  de  suco  position.  In  reality,  many  sucos  have  only  limited  lengths  of 
national  road  within  their  boundaries.  Workshop  participants  felt  that  this  aspect  should  be 
carefully monitored.

2. 

Assumptions 

a. 

Poverty Status 

 
49. 
Poverty  status  is  assessed  by  comparing  the  percentage  of  people  living  below  the 
poverty line estimated from the results of the questionnaire survey against the national figure of 
75 percent, quoted in the initial poverty assessment for East Timor, September 2000.  
 

b. 

Estimated Number of Beneficiaries 

 
50. 
These estimates are made according to 1998 census data, which gives populations for 
each suco in the country. Where this data has been updated since the 1999 conflict, it has been 
done  on  a  district  basis  and  is  therefore  not  comparable.    Estimates  have  been  made  by 
obtaining,  with  the  help  of  the  Government  staff  in  each  district,  the  sucos  that  are  situated 
along the road alignment and within the district town. The number of people that will benefit from 
improved road access is taken to be the total number of people in sucos situated along the road 
alignment and within the towns. The number of people that will benefit from paid employment is 
taken to be the total number of people in sucos situatated along the road alignment only. 
 

c. 

Assessment of Impact of Paid Employment 

 
51. 
The  impact  of  paid  employment,  either  for  civil  works  during  the  EIRP-2,  or  for  routine 
work  during  the  maintenance  period,  has  been  estimated  by  adding  predicted  payments  to 
current  household  incomes.  A  daily  rate  of  pay  of  Rp20,000  is  assumed,  and  the  effect  of 
employing one household member of one, two, and three days per month is assessed.  
 
52.  Within the sample, the total number of people living below the poverty lines is reduced 
considerably  when  cash  incomes  are  applied.  Table  A12.7  shows  the  effect  of  payment  of 
varying monthly sums to households:

53. 
As  a  result  of  the  EIRP-2,  a  high  proportion  of  beneficiaries  will  receive  incomes  that 
raise  and  sustain  them  above  the  poverty  line.  In  the  case  of  the  establishment  of  a  routine 
maintenance  regime,  the  effect  is  expected  to  be  fully  sustainable.  The  effect  of  paid 
employment is therefore rated as A. 

 

 

 

 82 

Appendix 12 

d. 

Assessment of Impact of Improved Road Access 

 
54. 
Poor  households  will  benefit  from  improved  road  access  indirectly,  through  reduced 
costs of access to markets and reduced journey times. These effects are expected to play a part 
in  raising  incomes  on  a  sustainable  basis,  and  importantly  to  raise  incomes  over  the  poverty 
line.  
 

e. 

Loan Amount Targeted to the Poor 

 
55. 
The  EIRP  is  considered  a  poverty  intervention  as  its  primary  purpose  is  to  enable  the 
future government to maintain the road network in order to allow rural poor people to engage in 
economic activity and to enable provision of essential services.  
 
F. 
 

Project Design Options 

1. 

Options for Increasing Poverty Impact 

 
56. 
The  poverty  impact  assessment  identifies  that  the  shortage  of  income-earning 
opportunities  is  a  major  concern  among  villagers  in  the  project  area.  The  shortage  of  cash  in 
village  economies  further  reduces  the  ability  of  villagers  to  establish  small  businesses  and 
acquire skills to bring them out of poverty.  
 
57. 
The  establishment  of  a  community-based  road  maintenance  regime  provides  a 
mechanism  for  providing  cash  to  rural  poor  communities,  as  well  as  the  means  to  raise  the 
incomes of beneficiaries above the poverty line. 

 
2. 

Gender 

 
Responses  by  beneficiaries  in  the  project  area  have  shown  that  physical  work  and  the 
58. 
control of funds are generally undertaken by men. These views were corroborated during village 
meetings  with  groups  of  beneficiaries,  although  in  most  cases  villagers  said  that  women  were 
regularly involved in tasks such as vegetation clearance. The fact that women are likely to have 
a  relatively  small  share  of  employment  and  the  allocation  of  the  proceeds  of  employment  is 
significant.  
 
59. 
Three  percent  of  households  interviewed  were  headed  by  women.  The  possible 
exclusion  of  such  households  from  access  to  paid  work  on  road  maintenance  is  an  issue  of 
concern.  
 
60. 
To  ensure  that  women  are  not  denied  the  benefits  of  access  to  paid  employment,  it  is 
recommended that the issue be discussed with village representatives when forming contracts 
for  labor,  and  the  representatives  should  agree  to  ensure  that  women  are  fully  entitled  to 
employment.  The  situation  should  be  monitored  when  community  labor  contracts  are  being 
implemented.  A  sample  of  women  within  the  community  should  be  interviewed  prior  to  the 
renewal of contracts. 
 

3. 

Participation 

 
The  establishment  of  a  community-based  road  maintenance  regime,  which  is  a  major 
61. 
component  of  the  EIRP-2,  is  participatory  in  nature.  The  views  of  communities  have  been 
obtained  in  developing  the  project  concept,  through  small-scale  meetings  held  at  sample 

 

 Appendix 12 

83

villages  along  the  alignment  of  both  roads.  The  majority  view  is  that  community-based  labor 
should be organized by means of contracts, arranged through elected village representatives.  
 

4. 

Governance 

 
62. 
East  Timor  is  in  the  process  of  forming  an  indigenous  government.  This  situation 
provides the opportunity to introduce concepts that have evolved from lessons learned through 
development endeavors elsewhere in Asia. The EIRP-2, as a strategically designed sustainable 
maintenance  initiative,  will  put  forward  a  strategy  for  management  of  the  road  sector  that 
embodies the principles of equitability and justice.  
 

5. 

Affordability 

 
63. 
The  use  of  project  funds  to  address  critical  landslide  hazard  areas  and  reduce  their 
impact  on  future  road  maintenance  funds  is  an  initiative  designed  specifically  for  the  issue  of 
affordability, as is the establishment of a community-based road maintenance regime.  
 
64.  With  regard  to  continued  sustainability  of  the  road  maintenance  system  that  will  be 
established, the rate of pay to villagers is a critical issue.  
 

The  EIRP-2  makes  use  of  labor  intensive  construction  and  road  maintenance 

6. 

Labor 

 
65. 
techniques. 
 

7. 

Other Risks/Vulnerabilities 

 
66. 
East Timor is in a postconflict situation, and has emerged from a recent period in which 
intense  violence  was  commonplace.  With  the  withdrawal  of  the  United  Nations  Transitional 
Administration in East Timor and peacekeeping forces following the formation of a new elected 
government,  a  period  will  ensue  in  which  poverty  levels  will  remain  high,  expectations  on  the 
performance  of  the  new  government  will  be  high,  and  difficulties  likely  as  the  new  nation  is 
formed. Localized conflict and violence, and periods of political unrest are possible. 
 
67. 
A  further  risk  concerns  the  difference  in  capability  among  neighboring  communities. 
Inevitably some communities are better organized and more capable of undertaking road work 
than others. At the same time, the village meetings and existing experience show that most rural 
communities in East Timor do not allow people from outside the community to undertake work in 
their village areas. This will lead to difficulties in the case of communities that do not perform, as 
communities  that  do  not  carry  out  road  maintenance  work  satisfactorily  are  likely  to  resist  the 
engagement  of  workers  from  outside  the  community  to  complete  the  work.  Strong  skill  and 
judgment by road authorities is required to overcome this risk. 
 
G. 
 
68. 
Positive  and  significant  impacts  of  the  EIRP-2  are  anticipated  for  the  beneficiary 
communities.  The  civil  works  component  will  enhance  the  reliability  of  road  access  for 
communities  around  the  country,  including  poorer  and  more  vulnerable  communities.  The 
establishment  of  a  community-based  road  maintenance  regime  will  provide  a  cost-effective 
means  of  ensuring  that  roads  are  maintained,  and  a  mechanism  for  providing  sustainable 
incomes to rural communities that have a strong need for income-generating opportunities.  

Conclusion 

 

 84 

Appendix 12 

 
69. 
Rural  communities  in  East  Timor  have  a  strong  structure  of  local  representation,  and 
village  representatives  are  capable  of  organizing  collective  activity,  such  as  the  road 
maintenance  activity  that  is  proposed.  The  initiative  is  therefore  appropriate  to  local  social 
conditions and structures.
